Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Sites: Tulane I-Corps Site for a Resurgent New Orleans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project creates an I-Corps Site at Tulane University located in New Orleans, LA. The project contributes to Tulane?s innovation-translation efforts and also to the post-Katrina New Orleans? ecosystem ? particularly in the areas of technology, energy, and the environment.

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace. Site funding is used to by academic institutions to catalyze teams (with amounts ranging from $1,000 to $3,000) whose technology concepts are likely candidates for commercialization. With the support and mentorship of the Sites, the teams learn first-hand about entrepreneurship and explore the transition of their ideas, devices, processes or other intellectual activities into the marketplace. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

Tulane will fund fifteen Tulane I-Corps SIte teams per year, to move funded research out of the laboratories into the marketplace and to support commercialization of promising ideas emerging from the classroom (particularly capstone design courses that have generated a track record of launching intellectual property and start-up companies).

Tulane has a critical mass of faculty researchers?many NSF-supported?willing to serve as Academic Advisors for Tulane I-Corps teams. Team Entrepreneurial Leads wil be recruited from students and postdocs and immersed in a curriculum emphasizing business model development based on Blank?s Customer Development process, Osterwalder?s Business Model Canvas, and Furr?s Nail It then Scale It process. Tulane and New Orleans have large pools of entrepreneurs willing to serve as Mentors to Tulane I-Corps teams?including emerging entrepreneurs from their interdisciplinary BioInnovation PhD Program and the Tulane Entrepreneurs Association (TEA).

Broader Impacts:
Anticipated program outcomes include increases in patentable technologies, start-up companies, and commercial licenses as well as students and faculty of the Tulane I-Corps teams who, by their deep involvement in innovation and entrepreneurship, will emerge as innovators and entrepreneurs.

The Tulane I-Corps Site will strengthen Tulane?s commitment to STEM education, women and underrepresented minorities, global health initiatives, and service to persons with disabilities. The Development of new technologies will expand economic development and reinforce the growing life sciences industry of New Orleans and surrounding regions.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tulane I-Corps Site for a Resurgent New Orleans was established in 2015 to support local development and commercialization of biomedical technologies, contribute to regional economic expansion, and assist in the growth of an innovative and entrepreneurial workforce through experiential training in I-Corps methodologies including Lean LaunchPad, Business Model Canvas, and Customer Discovery.  The project has provided a pathway for teams to the National I-Corps Program, and has contributed to the creation and delivery of a cohesive and coordinated suite of courses supporting interdisciplinary innovation and entrepreneurship at Tulane University.  I-Corps teams from Tulane have formed start-up companies, and have successfully raised their profiles and secured non-dilutive funding including through prestigious international business model competitions.  The robust convention industry in New Orleans was the proving ground for a novel I-Corps short-course tested in collaboration with National Innovation Network partners.  Intellectual merits further include the development of a new model of innovation and entrepreneurship linking actions and consequences across technological, business, and legal domains--drawing from our experience in introducing I-Corps to persons from a broad range of backgrounds and disciplines.  The novel short-course combined with the new model of innovation and entrepreneurship may represent a sustainable future for I-Corps at Tulane.


Last Modified: 08/03/2018
Modified by: Lars G Gilbertson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Tulane I-Corps Site for a Resurgent New Orleans was established in 2015 to support local development and commercialization of biomedical technologies, contribute to regional economic expansion, and assist in the growth of an innovative and entrepreneurial workforce through experiential training in I-Corps methodologies including Lean LaunchPad, Business Model Canvas, and Customer Discovery. The project has provided a pathway for teams to the National I-Corps Program, and has contributed to the creation and delivery of a cohesive and coordinated suite of courses supporting interdisciplinary innovation and entrepreneurship at Tulane University. I-Corps teams from Tulane have formed start-up companies, and have successfully raised their profiles and secured non-dilutive funding including through prestigious international business model competitions. The robust convention industry in New Orleans was the proving ground for a novel I-Corps short-course tested in collaboration with National Innovation Network partners. Intellectual merits further include the development of a new model of innovation and entrepreneurship linking actions and consequences across technological, business, and legal domains--drawing from our experience in introducing I-Corps to persons from a broad range of backgrounds and disciplines. The novel short-course combined with the new model of innovation and entrepreneurship may represent a sustainable future for I-Corps at Tulane. Last Modified: 08/03/2018 Submitted by: Lars G Gilbertson
